message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the limited availability of fossil fuels and the concept of their depletion over time. Fossil fuels, such as oil and natural gas, are non-renewable resources that are formed over millions of years and are being extracted at a much faster rate than they can be replenished. Therefore, it is likely that in one hundred years, fossil fuels may cease to exist or become extremely scarce. Option (A) is incorrect because fossil fuels are a finite resource and will not become more bountiful. Option (B) is also incorrect because the frequency of fossil fuels being available is not relevant to their potential depletion. Option (D) is not likely because fossil fuels have economic value and it is unlikely that they would become free.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the availability and depletion of fossil fuels. Fossil fuels are finite resources, which means that they are not replenished on a timescale relevant to human civilization. Therefore, it is likely that in one hundred years, fossil fuels may cease to exist or be significantly depleted. Option (A) is incorrect because it suggests that fossil fuels may become more abundant, which is unlikely given their limited availability. Option (B) is incorrect because it suggests that the frequency of fossil fuels would change, which is not relevant to their existence. Option (D) is incorrect because it suggests that they may become free, which is not related to their existence but rather their cost.

This question requires some understanding of the concept of fossil fuels and their limited availability. Fossil fuels are formed over millions of years from the remains of ancient plants and animals. They are not a renewable resource, meaning that once we extract and use them, they cannot be replaced within a human lifespan. Therefore, it is likely that in one hundred years, fossil fuels may either be completely depleted or very close to depletion, hence ceasing to exist as a readily available resource. Option (A) is incorrect because fossil fuels are not renewable and will not become more bountiful over time. Option (B) is unrelated to the availability of fossil fuels. Option (D) is unlikely because the extraction and refinement of fossil fuels involves significant costs.

This question requires some basic knowledge about fossil fuels and their availability. Fossil fuels are finite resources that are formed over millions of years. They are being depleted much faster than they are being formed, so it is likely that they will eventually cease to exist or become extremely limited in availability. Option (A) is incorrect because fossil fuels are not being replenished at the same rate they are being used. Option (B) is incorrect because the frequency of fossil fuels being available does not change over time. Option (D) is incorrect because there is currently a cost associated with fossil fuels and it is unlikely they will become free in the future.
